conclusion: Determine how the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time changes from state C to state D in the Stirling cycle.
The Stirling cycle consists of two isothermal processes and two isochoric processes. A→B and C→D are isothermal, meaning the temperature remains constant.
At state C, the gas is at pressure \( P_C \) and volume \( V_C \). Process C→D is isothermal, so temperature \( T \) at state C is the same as at state D.
At state D, the gas is at different pressure \( P_D \) and volume \( V_D \). Process C→D is isothermal, so temperature remains constant, but pressure and volume change.
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is related to the pressure of the gas. Pressure is proportional to the number of collisions.
From the P-V diagram, pressure at state D (\( P_D \)) is lower than at state C (\( P_C \)), so \( P_D < P_C \).
Since pressure decreases from state C to state D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time also decreases.
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time decreases from state C to state D.
